reference.text: impedance networks, e.g. attenuators, H03H; control of transmission in lines H04B3/04

note.note-paragraph:
This subclass covers:
- control of gain of amplifiers or frequency-changers,
- control of frequency range of amplifiers,
- limiting amplitude or rate of change of amplitude
Attention is drawn to the Note following the title of subclass H03F.

title-part.text: Details of arrangements for controlling amplification

CPC-specific-text.text: for arrangements combined with means for generating a controlling signal, or these means per se, see the other main groups of H03G
Circuits characterised by the type of controlling devices operated by a controlling current or voltage signal
the device being at least one of the amplifying tubes of the amplifier
the device being at least one of the amplifying solid state elements of the amplifier
using discontinuously variable devices, e.g. switch-operated

title-part.text: Remote control of amplification, tone, or bandwidth

reference.text: remote control in general G05 , G08 ; combined with remote tuning or selection of resonant circuits H03J

title-part.text: Modifications of control circuit to reduce distortion caused by control

reference.text: modifications to reduce influence of variations of internal impedance of amplifying elements caused by control H03F1/08

title-part.text: Gain control in amplifiers or frequency changers

CPC-specific-text.text: without distortion of the input signal

reference.text: gated amplifiers H03F3/72 ; peculiar to television receivers H04N

CPC-specific-text.text: Control of digital or coded signals
Control by varying the supply voltage
Control dependent on the supply voltage

reference.text: ; combined with volume compression or expansion H03G7/00

CPC-specific-text.text: controlling or controlled by the (local) oscillators of a (super)heterodyne receiver

title-part.text: Control dependent upon ambient noise level or sound level
Muting amplifier when no signal is present

CPC-specific-text.text: or when only weak signals are present, or caused by the presence of noise, e.g. squelch systems
in amplifiers suitable for low-frequencies, e.g. audio amplifiers
the gain being discontinuously variable, e.g. controlled by switching
in high-frequency amplifiers or in frequency-changers
in modulators, frequency-changers, transmitters or power amplifiers

reference.text: transmission power control in bidirectional transmission systems H04W52/04

CPC-specific-text.text: for intermittent signals, e.g. burst signals
or in frequency-changers used in a (super)heterodyne receiver
using at least one diode as controlling device
using at least one transistor as controlling device, the transistor being used as a variable impedance device
Circuits generating control signals for both R.F. and I.F. stages
Circuits generating control signals when no carrier is present, or in SSB, CW or pulse receivers
Circuits generating control signals for digitally modulated signals
in receivers or transmitters for electromagnetic waves other than radiowaves, e.g. lightwaves
Control of digital or coded signals

title-part.text: the control being dependent upon ambient noise level or sound level
Muting amplifier when no signal is present

CPC-specific-text.text: or when only weak signals are present, or caused by the presence of noise signals, e.g. squelch systems
Muting when no signals or only weak signals are present
Muting when some special characteristic of the signal is sensed which distinguishes it from noise, e.g. using speech detector
Muting responsive to the amount of noise
Muting during a short period of time when noise pulses are detected, i.e. blanking
dependent on the rate of noise pulses
Muting in response to a mechanical action or to power supply variations, e.g. during tuning; Click removal circuits

reference.text: variable bandpass or bandstop filters H03H7/12

using discontinuously variable devices, e.g. switch-operated

Indexing scheme relating to subclass H03G

being in power supply of the amplifier
